abstractText: 33 The ability to remember what happened where and when constitutes the basic fabric of 34 our memories and who we are. Forming and recalling memories depends on detecting novelty, 35 building associations to prior knowledge, and dynamically retrieving context-relevant 36 information. Previous studies have scrutinized the neural machinery for individual components 37 of recognition or associative memory under laboratory conditions, such as recalling elements 38 from arbitrary lists of words or pictures. In this study, we implemented a well-known card39 matching game that integrates multiple components of memory formation together in a 40 naturalistic setting to investigate the dynamic neural processes underlying complex natural 41 human memory. We recorded intracranial field potentials from 1,750 depth or subdural 42 electrodes implanted in 20 patients with pharmacologically-intractable epilepsy while they were 43 performing the task. We leveraged generalized linear models to simultaneously assess the 44 relative contribution of neural responses to distinct task components. Neural activity in the 45 gamma frequency band signaled novelty and graded degrees of familiarity, represented the 46 strength and outcome of associative recall, and finally reflected visual feedback on a trial-by-trial 47 basis. The large-scale data and models enable dissociating and at the same time dynamically 48 tracing the different cognitive components during fast, complex, and natural human memory 49 behaviors. 50 51 Significance 52 53 Different aspects of memory like recognition, association, and recall have often been 54 studied in isolation under laboratory conditions. Here we implemented a task that naturally 55 integrates recognition, association, and retrieval, mimicking real-world memory experiences. 56 Recording invasive intracranial field potentials from the human brain, this study shows that 57 neural activity in the gamma frequency band in neocortical areas in temporal and frontal cortex 58 reflects temporally overlapping yet computationally dissociable mental processes during 59 dynamic memory formation. 60 61 62 . sections.text:
The ability to remember what happened where and when constitutes the basic fabric of 34
our memories and who we are. Forming and recalling memories depends on detecting novelty, 35
building associations to prior knowledge, and dynamically retrieving context-relevant 36
information. Previous studies have scrutinized the neural machinery for individual components 37
of recognition or associative memory under laboratory conditions, such as recalling elements 38
from arbitrary lists of words or pictures. In this study, we implemented a well-known card-39
matching game that integrates multiple components of memory formation together in a 40
naturalistic setting to investigate the dynamic neural processes underlying complex natural 41
human memory. We recorded intracranial field potentials from 1,750 depth or subdural 42
electrodes implanted in 20 patients with pharmacologically-intractable epilepsy while they were 43
performing the task. We leveraged generalized linear models to simultaneously assess the 44
relative contribution of neural responses to distinct task components. Neural activity in the 45
gamma frequency band signaled novelty and graded degrees of familiarity, represented the 46
strength and outcome of associative recall, and finally reflected visual feedback on a trial-by-trial 47
basis. The large-scale data and models enable dissociating and at the same time dynamically 48
tracing the different cognitive components during fast, complex, and natural human memory 49
behaviors. 50
51
Significance 52 53 Different aspects of memory like recognition, association, and recall have often been 54
studied in isolation under laboratory conditions. Here we implemented a task that naturally 55
integrates recognition, association, and retrieval, mimicking real-world memory experiences. 56
Recording invasive intracranial field potentials from the human brain, this study shows that 57
neural activity in the gamma frequency band in neocortical areas in temporal and frontal cortex 58
reflects temporally overlapping yet computationally dissociable mental processes during 59
dynamic memory formation. 60
61
62
Main Text 63
Introduction 64
Episodic memories constitute the essential backbone of our identities. Neural circuits 65
must extract, store, and retrieve information about what, when, and where of specific life events. 66
In stark contrast to most efforts in current artificial intelligence algorithms, the formation and 67
retrieval of episodic memories occurs in a largely unsupervised fashion, with single or limited 68
exposures, and leads to continual learning of new events that are automatically linked to previous 69
experiences. Despite extensive efforts at the molecular, physiological, and behavioral levels, our 70
mechanistic understanding of the formation of episodic memories remains limited. 71
The formation and recall of memories require assessing novelty versus familiarity, 72
building bridges between sensory inputs and prior knowledge, and effectively retrieving 73
information in the context of current task demands or internal thoughts. There is extensive 74
literature examining neural responses during separate components of this process. A large 75
number of studies have focused on tasks that involve presenting a list of items, such as words, 76
pictures, or video clips, and either recalling items from these lists or assessing recognition 77
memory for those items (e.g., (1-12)). Another prominent experimental paradigm inspired by 78
research in rodents has focused on spatial navigation (e.g., (13-16)). 79
Judging an item as novel is necessary for its successful memory encoding (17), and 80
recognizing an item as familiar facilitates memory retrieval (18). Several studies have 81
documented correlates of recognition memory for novelty versus familiarity, primarily but not 82
exclusively, in medial temporal lobe structures in rodents, monkeys, and humans (1, 2, 4, 5, 7, 8, 83
13, 19-23). Both novel and familiar items need to be incorporated into the body of prior 84
knowledge by forming novel associations. Associative memory has been commonly investigated 85
by having participants learn pairs of items and then recall one of the two items or assess whether 86
a given association is correct or not (e.g., (24-33)). Although recognition memory and associative 87
memory have been largely studied separately, they are not independent in real-world memory 88
tasks. Successful implementation of associative memory is contingent on basic recognition 89
processes. 90
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licenseavailable under a (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is made
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.03.27.534384doi: bioRxiv preprint
To connect and dissociate different components of memory formation in a natural and 91
complex behavior, here we recorded intracranial field potentials from 20 patients with 92
pharmacologically resilient epilepsy while they played a classical card matching game, 93
colloquially known as the "Memory" game (Figure 1, Movie S1). We focused on the neural 94
activities in the gamma frequency band (30-150 Hz), which are thought to indirectly reflect the 95
synchronous firing of ensembles of neurons that support neuronal communication as well as 96
cortical computation (34-38). We constructed generalized linear models to characterize how 97
neural responses are modulated by the different behavioral components involved in the task. 98
The results show how neural circuits transition from representing novelty and graded degrees of 99
familiarity to the strength and outcome of associative recall and reward feedback on a trial-by-100
trial basis. 101
102
Results 103
104
We recorded intracranial field potentials (IFPs) from 20 patients with pharmacologically 105
intractable epilepsy implanted with depth electrodes (Table S1, one participant also had subdural 106
surface electrodes). Participants played a memory-matching game (Figure 1, Movie S1, Methods). 107
Each trial consisted of two self-paced clicks. Clicking on a tile revealed an image (Figure 1A). 108
Image categories included person, animal, food, vehicle, and indoor scenes. If the two tiles in a 109
trial contained the same image (match, Figure 1B), the two tiles turned green and could not be 110
clicked again for the remainder of the block. If the two images were different (mismatch, Figure 111
1A and 1C), the two tiles turned black and could be clicked again. Participants started in a 3×3 112
tile board block like the one shown in Figure 1 and progressed to more difficult blocks (4×4, 5×5, 113
6×6, or 7×7 tiles). All tiles had a corresponding match, except for one tile in the boards with an 114
odd number of tiles (3x3, 5x5, and 7x7). 115
116
Mismatch trials showed longer reaction times and were associated with less frequent and less 117
recent exposure to matching pairs 118
119
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licenseavailable under a (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is made
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.03.27.534384doi: bioRxiv preprint
The average number of clicks per tile increased with difficulty (board size), as expected 120
(Figure 2A). All participants performed much better than a memoryless model (random clicking, 121
p<0.001, here and in subsequent tests unless stated otherwise: permutation test, 5,000 iterations, 122
one-tailed) and performed worse than a model assuming perfect memory (p<0.001, Figure 2A). 123
The reaction time (RT) was defined as the time interval between the first and second clicks within 124
a trial (Figure 1A). The reaction time was longer for mismatch than match trials for all board sizes 125
(p<0.007, Figure 2B). 126
For a tile in a given trial, we defined n-since-last-click (nslc) as the number of clicks elapsed 127
since the last time the same tile was clicked (Figure 1A-B). As expected, nslc increased with board 128
size (p<0.001, linear regression, F-test, Figure 2C-D). For the 2nd tile, nslc was larger in mismatch 129
compared to match trials for all board sizes except the 3x3 case (p<0.001, Figure 2D), a reflection 130
of the decay in memory for tiles that were not seen recently. The larger nslc in mismatch trials 131
also held for the 1st tile only for the 7x7 board size (p<0.001, Figure 2C). If the participants believe 132
that they know the locations of both tiles in a matching pair, a reasonable strategy is to click first 133
the tile they are less sure about, likely because they have seen this tile earlier rather than later in 134
the block. This strategy accounts for the differences between the 1st tile (Figure 2C) and 2nd tile 135
(Figure 2D). 136
For a tile in a given trial, we defined n-since-pair (nsp) as the number of clicks since the 137
last time when its matching pair was seen (Figure 1A, C). As expected, nsp increased with board 138
size given the increased difficulty (p<0.001, linear regression, F-test, Figure 2E-2F). Additionally, 139
the more recent the tile's matching pair was seen, the more likely the trial was a match. Thus, 140
nsp was larger in mismatch compared to match trials in all cases except the 3x3 board size for 141
the 1st tile (p<0.001, Figure 2E). For the 2nd tile, nsp for any match trial was always one because 142
the matching pair would have been revealed in the previous click, by definition. Thus, there was 143
a large difference between nsp between match and mismatch trials (p<0.001, Figure 2F). 144
We performed infrared eye-tracking on ten healthy participants while they performed the 145
same task. Participants fixated on the tile they clicked, both for the first and second tiles, and 146
both for match and mismatch trials (Figure S1). For the first tile, there was no difference in the 147
dynamics of saccades towards and away from the target tile between match and mismatch trials 148
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licenseavailable under a (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is made
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.03.27.534384doi: bioRxiv preprint
(Figure S1A) after equalizing the RT and the distances between the 1st and the 2nd tiles. For the 149
second tile, there was no difference in the dynamics of saccades toward the target tile before the 150
click. However, for approximately 1 second after the 2nd click, the distance to the center of the 151
tile was, on average, 1.76 dva (degrees of visual angle) larger for match than mismatch trials 152
(Figure S1B). This small difference may be attributed to participants' lingering slightly longer 153
during mismatch trials, arguably in an effort to remember the tile. 154
155
Neural signals reflect novelty and familiarity 156
157
We recorded intracranial field potentials from 1,750 electrodes (Table S2). We excluded 158
582 electrodes due to bipolar referencing, locations in pathological sites, or signals containing 159
artifacts (Methods). We included in the analyses 676 bipolarly referenced electrodes in the gray 160
matter (Figure 3) and 492 in the white matter (Figure S2). Table S2 describes electrode locations 161
separated by brain region and hemisphere. Although the white matter is presumed to contain 162
mostly myelinated axons, previous studies have shown that intracranial field potential signals 163
from the white matter can demonstrate biologically meaningful information (39, 40). Such signals 164
could reflect small errors in electrode localization on the order of ~2 millimeters and also the 165
spread of intracranial field potential signals over 1 to 5 millimeters (35, 36, 41-43), implying that 166
white matter electrodes may still capture activity from gray matter. Indeed, we show here that 167
electrodes in the white matter reveal task-relevant properties and therefore included electrodes 168
in the white matter in our analyses. To avoid confusion about the origin of the signals, we focused 169
on the gray matter electrodes in the main text and reported results from electrodes in the white 170
matter in the Supplementary Material. None of the conclusions in this study would change if we 171
were to report the results from electrodes in the gray matter exclusively. 172
We built two generalized linear models (GLM) to characterize how the neural responses 173
depended on the cognitive demands of each trial. The first model focused on the neural 174
responses to the 1st tile, and the second model on the 2nd tile. In both cases, we focused on 175
predicting the area under the curve (AUC) of the gamma band power (30-150 Hz) in each trial 176
(Methods). For the first GLM, the time window started when the 1st tile was clicked and ended 177
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licenseavailable under a (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is made
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.03.27.534384doi: bioRxiv preprint
at a time corresponding to the 90th percentile of the distribution of reaction times (time 178
difference between the 1st and the 2nd clicks, Figure 1A). This criterion was a reasonable tradeoff 179
between minimizing overlap with responses after the 2nd tile and maximally capturing 180
information before the 2nd tile. For the second model, the time window started with the 2nd click 181
and ended one second afterward. 182
We considered 15 predictors for the GLM models, including whether a trial was a match 183
or not, reaction time, n-since-last-click (nslc), and n-since-pair (nsp), the variables introduced in 184
Figures 1-2. We also included additional predictors: first-click (whether a tile was clicked for the 185
first time), n-times-seen (number of times an image had been seen), next-match (whether the 186
subsequent trial was a match), board size, x and y position of the clicked tile within the board, 187
distance between the first and the second tiles, and whether the image contained a person, 188
animal, food, or vehicle. Table 1 lists all the predictors and their definitions. Since several 189
predictors were correlated with each other (Figure S3A-B), we computed the variance inflation 190
factor (VIF) (44), a metric commonly used to account for correlations between predictors in 191
generalized linear models. The VIF of each predictor was smaller than 3 for all participants (Figure 192
S3C-D). Therefore, the correlations between predictors did not harm the performance of the 193
models (Methods). 194
When the first tile in a trial was clicked, its status in memory guided the following actions. 195
If it was a new image, the participant needed to encode it in memory for future retrieval. Thus, 196
the ability to detect novelty is the first step for successful encoding. The predictor first-click 197
described novelty and had a value of 1 whenever a tile was seen for the first time and 0 otherwise. 198
If a tile had been viewed before, it would appear familiar to the participant, and the degree of 199
familiarity depended on how long ago that tile had been seen last. The predictor n-since-last-click 200
(Figure 1A-B, Figure 2C-D) described familiarity; the smaller nslc, the more familiar the tile is 201
because that same tile was seen more recently. 202
Figure 4A-D shows the neural activity of an electrode located in the right lateral 203
orbitofrontal cortex (arrow in Figure 4D), whose responses to the first tile correlated with novelty. 204
The GLM analysis indicated that first-click was a significant predictor of the neural responses 205
(Figure 4A). The neural responses to the first tile showed a decrease in activity for novel tiles 206
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licenseavailable under a (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is made
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.03.27.534384doi: bioRxiv preprint
compared to tiles that had been seen before (Figure 4B), which could also be readily seen in 207
individual trials (Figure 4C). This decrease in activity is reflected by the negative sign in the GLM 208
first-click predictor (Figure 4A). 209
Novelty was a significant predictor of the neural responses after the first tile (p<0.01, GLM) 210
for 50 electrodes in the gray matter (7.4% of the total, Table S3A, Figure 4D) and 33 electrodes 211
in the white matter (6.7% of the total, Table S3B). The lateral orbitofrontal (LOF) cortex and pars 212
opercularis contained significantly more electrodes than expected by chance (p<0.01, Methods). 213
Figure 4E-H show the neural activity of an electrode located in the left pars opercularis 214
(arrow in Figure 4H), whose responses to the first tile correlated with familiarity. The GLM 215
analysis indicated that both n-since-last-click (nslc) and first-click were significant predictors of 216
the neural responses (p<0.001, GLM, Figure 4E). Novel tiles (completely unfamiliar tiles, Figure 217
4F, blue) elicited strong responses, followed by less familiar tiles (higher nslc, Figure 4F, yellow). 218
Familiar tiles (nslc=1, i.e., tiles that had just been seen in the preceding trial) elicited almost no 219
response (Figure 4F, red). The strong correlation between the neural responses, novelty, and 220
familiarity can also be readily appreciated in individual trials (Figure 4G). 221
The reaction time was also a significant predictor for the neural responses recorded from 222
this electrode (Figure 4E). However, the differences in neural responses signaling novelty and 223
distinct degrees of familiarity cannot be explained by differences in reaction time. The differences 224
in neural responses associated with novelty and familiarity persisted after reaction time 225
equalization (see vertical dashed lines indicating equalized RT in Figure 4F). 226
The nslc predictor was statistically significant (p<0.01, GLM) in 45 gray matter electrodes 227
(6.7% of the total, Table S4A, Figure 4H) and 32 white matter electrodes (6.5%, Table S4B, Figure 228
S4D). Figure S4 shows an example electrode located in the white matter whose responses 229
correlated with novelty and familiarity. The majority of electrodes (82.2%) showed a positive 230
correlation between the neural responses and nslc as illustrated in Figure 4E-G. The remaining 231
electrodes (17.8%) showed a negative correlation, i.e., stronger neural responses for more 232
familiar items. Figure S5 depicts an example electrode located in the right pars opercularis 233
showing a negative correlation between familiarity and neural responses. 234
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licenseavailable under a (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is made
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.03.27.534384doi: bioRxiv preprint
Both the electrode in Figure 4E-H and the one in Figure S5 revealed first-click as a 235
significant predictor in addition to nslc, meaning that their responses not only reflected the 236
familiarity gradient but also represented novelty. The electrodes that showed both first-click and 237
n-since-last-click as significant predictors (20 electrodes) are denoted by red circles in Figure 4D 238
and Figure 4H. Among these 20 electrodes, the signs of the t-statistic for the first-click and n-239
since-last-click predictors were consistent for 18 electrodes (16 positive and 2 negative). Only 240
two electrodes exhibited opposite signs. These results indicate that novelty largely resembles 241
extremely low familiarity in terms of the underlying neural responses. 242
243
Neural signals predict correct retrieval 244
245
After seeing the 1st tile, participants attempt to find the tile's pair. If the 1st tile's pair was 246
never encountered before, this is a random choice among the unseen tiles. If the tile's pair is 247
unfamiliar, recalling a match is error-prone and often leads to mismatches (Figure 2E). For highly 248
familiar cases, participants can retrieve the correct location to find the match tile. Therefore, we 249
asked whether the neural responses after exposure to the first tile and before seeing the 2nd tile 250
could predict successful retrieval. 251
Figure 5 shows the neural activity of an electrode located in the right lateral orbitofrontal 252
cortex (arrow in Figure 5E), whose responses were predictive of successful retrieval. The GLM 253
analysis indicated that match was a significant predictor of the neural responses (p<0.001, Figure 254
5A). This electrode showed stronger responses during match trials (Figure 5B, green) than during 255
mismatch trials (Figure 5B, black). These differences can even be appreciated in single trials 256
(compare Figure 5C versus Figure 5D). Of note, these differences are evident shortly after 257
visualization of the first tile, with a peak at 500 ms after clicking the first tile, well before clicking 258
the second tile, when the participant did not know for certain yet whether the trial would be a 259
match or not. Thus, the strong neural differences between match and mismatch trials reflect the 260
participant's internal retrieval of the correct pairs' locations. 261
Whether a trial was a match or not was a significant predictor of the neural responses for 262
32 electrodes in the gray matter (4.7% of the total, Table S5A, Figure 5E) and 30 electrodes in 263
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licenseavailable under a (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is made
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.03.27.534384doi: bioRxiv preprint
the white matter (6% of the total, Table S5B, Figure S6). For an example electrode in the white 264
matter see Figure S6. In most cases (91 %), neural activity was higher during match trials than 265
during mismatch trials, as illustrated in Figure 5. The locations of all these electrodes, shown in 266
Figure 5E (gray matter) and Figure S6 (white matter), reveal that the majority were located in the 267
lateral orbitofrontal (LOF) cortex, the medial temporal lobe, and the insula. The LOF cortex 268
contained significantly more electrodes than expected by chance (p<0.01, Methods). 269
The peak in neural activity occurred at approximately 500 ms after the 1st click (Figure 5B). 270
As discussed in the previous section, the match predictor correlated with several other predictors 271
(Figure S3). However, the GLM analysis shows that the match's presence, but not other 272
predictors, accounts for the neural responses (Figure 5A). To further establish this point, Figure 273
S7A shows the responses of this same electrode, in the same format as Figure 5B, after equalizing 274
the n-since-last-click (nslc) distributions for match and mismatch trials by subsampling the data. 275
The same conclusions hold in this case. Furthermore, Figure S7B shows each match trial's gamma 276
power AUC versus the value of n-since-last-click and Figure S7C displays the same data from 277
mismatch trials. The variable nslc did not account for the neural responses in either case (p>0.18, 278
linear regression). Similar conclusions hold for the other predictors. 279
Figure S8 shows another example electrode located in the left middle temporal gyrus 280
where the match was a significant predictor for the gamma band activity between the 1st and 2nd 281
tiles. Similar to the LOF electrode in Figure 5, the gamma power during match trials was higher 282
than during mismatch trials. However, the pattern of modulation in this electrode was sustained 283
rather than transient (compare Figure S8 versus Figure 5B-D). The change in gamma power was 284
also evident in individual trials (Figure S8B-C). These observations suggest that the middle 285
temporal and lateral orbitofrontal regions might be functionally distinct during memory retrieval. 286
In sum, these results indicate that even before the actual realization of whether a trial was a 287
match or mismatch (i.e., before the onset of the 2nd tile), there were distinct neural responses 288
that were predictive of the trial's outcome. 289
290
Neural signals reflect the strength of memory retrieval 291
292
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licenseavailable under a (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is made
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.03.27.534384doi: bioRxiv preprint
In addition to reflecting the outcome of a given trial (match versus mismatch), we 293
considered the n-since-pair (nsp) predictor as a proxy for the degree of confidence or strength of 294
memory retrieval. The smaller nsp, the more recently the tile's pair had been seen (Figure 2E-F). 295
This predictor is different from n-since-last-click, which indicates how recently the same tile, 296
rather than its pair, had been seen (Figure 1). We considered only match trials for this predictor 297
(n-since-pair*match) because there was no successful retrieval of the tile's pair in mismatch trials. 298
Figure 6 shows an example electrode in the left middle temporal gyrus (arrow in Figure 299
6E). In contrast with the electrode in Figure 5, both the match predictor and the nsp predictor 300
were significant in the GLM analysis (Figure 6A). The t-statistic for nsp was negative, indicating a 301
decrease in gamma band power for matching pairs that were more distant in memory. Indeed, 302
responses were strongest for those tiles whose pairs had been seen less than 2 clicks ago (Figure 303
6B, red) and weakest when matching pairs had been seen more than 10 clicks ago (Figure 6B, 304
purple). There was a negative correlation between the area under the curve (AUC) of the gamma 305
band power and nsp (Figure 6C, p<0.001, linear regression). This correlation disappeared when 306
considering mismatch trials (Figure 6D, p=0.66, linear regression), suggesting that the 307
relationship between the neural signals and memory strength was contingent on successful 308
retrieval. 309
The nsp predictor was statistically significant (p<0.01, GLM) in 15 electrodes in the gray 310
matter (2.2% of the total, Table S6A, Figure 6E) and 9 electrodes in the white matter (1.8% of the 311
total, Table S6B, Figure S9E). For an example electrode located in the white matter, see Figure 312
S9. Most of these electrodes showed a negative t-statistic, as in the example in Figure 6, and 313
three electrodes (20%) showed the reverse effect (i.e., an increase in the neural signal for more 314
distant associative memories). For most of these electrodes (73.3%), match was also a significant 315
predictor, as illustrated by the example in Figure 6A, indicating that the neural signals encoded 316
both successful retrieval and memory strength. 317

We evaluated whether the neural responses within a brain region could predict if a trial 380
was a match or a mismatch (Methods). For this analysis, we considered only those brain regions 381
with more than 12 electrodes combining all participants (Methods). Figure 8 shows the average 382
decoding performance of an SVM classifier after 200 iterations of 5-fold cross-validation. At each 383

chance (p<0.01, Methods) during the 1st tile (Figure 8A). The lateral orbitofrontal and middle 387
temporal cortex also showed accuracy above chance (>60%, Figure 8A), albeit not statistically 388
significant. As expected based on the responses of individual electrodes, the decoding accuracy 389
was higher after the 2nd tile compared to the 1st tile. After the 2nd tile, multiple brain regions 390
showed accuracy above chance (p<0.01, Figure 8B). The lateral orbitofrontal cortex, insula, 391

394
Discussion 395
396
In this study, we followed the dynamics of neural signals during a natural memory task 397
based on a classical card-matching game. Participants performed the task very well, slightly 398
worse than expected by a perfect memory model (Figure 2A), showing increased reaction times 399
during mismatch trials (Figure 2B) as well as decay of memory traces with time since encoding 400
(Figure 2C-F). The extensive sampling of brain regions afforded by studying the neural activity of 401
more than 1,000 electrodes across 20 participants (Figure 3 and Figure S2) enabled us to track 402
neural responses during each of the steps required in the task with broad brain coverage. 403
The first step to encode tile information is to correctly determine whether a tile is novel 404
or not. We refer to the ability to detect novelty and familiarity as non-associative recognition 405
memory (6, 27). Assessment of novelty and familiarity orchestrate encoding and maintenance 406
strategies (17, 46). We found strong neural responses that signal novelty and familiarity (Figure 407
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licenseavailable under a (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is made
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.03.27.534384doi: bioRxiv preprint
4, Figure S4, S5 and S10, Table S3, S4, S7 and S8). Several electrodes responded both to novelty 408
and familiarity. In these cases, novel and highly unfamiliar items triggered similar neural 409
responses (Figure 4F-G, Figure S4B-C, Figure S10B-C). The lateral orbitofrontal cortex, the pars 410
opercularis, and the medial temporal lobe contained a preponderance of electrodes signaling 411
novelty and familiarity. These responses are reminiscent of novelty and familiarity signals that 412
have typically been described in tasks involving a sequence of images presented with occasional 413
repetitions (6, 7, 10, 47) but are not restricted to the medial temporal lobe. While some 414
electrodes may also encode information about the image content (Figure 4E), the fact that 415
correlates of familiarity can be observed at the level of intracranial field potentials suggests that 416
the representation of familiarity may not be content-specific. Different contents with the same 417
level of familiarity may induce the same response, consistent with the observation that neurons 418
involved in memory formation are rarely sharply tuned to particular sensory features (31). 419
After seeing the first tile in a trial, participants could estimate whether they remembered 420
the location of its pair and, thus, whether they would get a match or not. Participants link the 421
first tile with its pair to internally predict where to click next. Indeed, neural responses strongly 422
reflected not only these predictions (Figure 5, Figures S6, S8) but also the internal estimate of 423
the strength or the confidence of these predictions (Figure 6). Even though participants could not 424
know for sure yet whether the trial would be a match or not, the neural signals demonstrated a 425
large difference between match and mismatch trials after the first tile and before the revelation 426
of the second tile. These differences were either transient (Figure 5) or sustained (Figure S8). We 427
speculate that transient increases in activity during match trials might signal the sudden 428
realization and high confidence about the trial outcome (match or mismatch). In contrast, 429
sustained responses may correspond to the active retrieval processes. It is possible that sustained 430
activity could arise due to averaging across temporally shifted transient activities from individual 431
neurons (48). However, it has been reported that single neurons in the hippocampus can also 432
show sustained firing rate increase for successful associative retrieval (49). Extensive work has 433
documented the importance of the hippocampus and surrounding structures in the MTL in 434
associative memory (e.g., (6, 29, 49, 50)). In addition to the MTL, the current results show that 435
other areas, such as the lateral orbitofrontal cortex, also play a critical role in associative recall. 436
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licenseavailable under a (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is made
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.03.27.534384doi: bioRxiv preprint
Many studies have focused on studying memory for a list of sequentially presented words, 437
images, or other stimuli (5, 11, 17, 21, 27, 47, 51). Other studies have examined memory 438
formation in naturalistic or real-world scenarios at the behavioral level (52-56). The task 439
introduced here is in between these two extremes. The card-matching game is more realistic and 440
adds multiple complexities compared to a sequence of individual images or words. Yet, it allows 441
for a high level of control over stimulus timing and experimental parameters that are difficult to 442
achieve when studying memory in real-world scenarios. The neurophysiological responses 443
tracked multiple steps in the task, from detecting novel tiles to their subsequent encoding, 444
association, retrieval, and feedback. 445
Complex and natural tasks necessarily depend on the interplay of multiple intercorrelated 446
variables. To tame the complexity of these different variables, we used generalized linear models 447
to quantitatively assess the influence of distinct predictors on the neural responses. Through 448
these GLM analyses, we could characterize neurophysiological responses that were largely 449
governed by individual predictors after accounting for the correlations among predictors (Figure 450
S3). While focusing on any one predictor, these results were corroborated by subsampling the 451
data to equalize other predictor variables that potentially affect the neural responses. Given the 452
complexity of the task and the nature of the intracranial field potential signals studied here, it is 453
remarkable that it is possible to isolate individual aspects of the task reflected in the 454
neurophysiological responses. 455
The high temporal resolution, extensive spatial sampling, and systematic computational 456
models provide an opportunity to characterize the dynamics of complex naturalistic tasks. These 457
observations provide initial steps to further our understanding of how different components of 458
encoding and retrieval interact during the formation of natural memory events. 459
460
Methods 461
462
Task paradigm 463
Participants performed our implementation of the classical memory matching game 464
(Figure 1, Movie S1). The game involves remembering the location and content of a set of tiles 465
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licenseavailable under a (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is made
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.03.27.534384doi: bioRxiv preprint
to find all the matching pairs. A square board containing n × n tiles was shown throughout each 466
block. In the beginning, all tiles were shown in black. In each trial, participants chose one tile, and 467
then a second tile, by clicking on them in a self-paced fashion. Upon clicking, the tile revealed a 468
common object like a cat or an indoor scene like a kitchen. At the end of each trial, either the 469
two tiles revealed the same content (match) or not (mismatch). If the tiles matched, then the two 470
tiles turned green 1,000 ms after the second click, and the two tiles could not be clicked again for 471
the remainder of the block. If the tiles did not match, they turned black 1,000 ms after the second 472
click and could be clicked again in subsequent trials. When all tiles turned green, i.e., all matches 473
were found, the block ended, and another block began. During each block, the map between 474
positions and objects was fixed. The game always started with a block of size 3×3 and progressed 475
to more difficult blocks (4×4, 5×5, 6×6, and finally 7×7). Blocks with an odd number of tiles (3×3, 476
5×5, and 7×7) contained one distractor object (a human face) with no corresponding pair. For 477
each block except the 3×3 board, there was a limit for the total time elapsed (2 minutes for 4×4, 478
3.3 min for 5×5, 4.8 min for 6×6, and 8.2 min for 7x7). If a participant did not complete a block 479
within the time limit, the block ended, and a new, easier block started by reducing the board size 480
n by 1, except when n=7, where it was reduced by 2. Conversely, when participants successfully 481
completed a block with a board of size n within the allotted time limit, they moved on to a more 482
difficult block by increasing n by 1. When participants completed an n=7 block, they performed 483
further n=7 blocks. There was no image repetition across blocks. 484
All the images were from the Microsoft COCO 2017 validation dataset (57) and were 485
rendered in grayscale and square shape. We included a balanced number of pictures from 5 486
categories: person, animal, food, vehicle, and indoor scenes. All the images were rendered on a 487
13-inch Apple MacBook Pro laptop. The size of each tile was 0.75×0.75 inches (approximately 2x2 488
degrees of visual angle, dva) and the separation between two adjacent tiles was 0.125 inch (0.33 489
dva) for board size n=7 and 0.25 inch (0.67 dva) for the others. The game implementation was 490
written and presented using the Psychtoolbox extension (58, 59) in Matlab_2016b (Mathworks, 491
Natick, MA). 492
493
Epilepsy participants and recording procedures 494

We recorded intracranial field potentials from 20 patients with pharmacologically 495
intractable epilepsy (12-52 years old, 9 female, Table S1) undergoing monitoring at Boston 496
Children's Hospital (Boston, US), Brigham and Women's Hospital (Boston, US), and Xuanwu 497
Hospital (Beijing, China). All recording sessions were seizure-free. All patients had normal or 498
corrected-to-normal vision. The study protocol was approved by each hospital's institutional 499
review board. Experiments were run under patients' or their legal guardians' informed consent. 500
One patient at Brigham and Women's Hospital (BWH) was implanted with both stereo 501
encephalography (sEEG) and electrocorticography (ECoG) electrodes, while all other patients had 502
only sEEG electrodes (Ad-tech, USA; ALCIS, France). Intracranial field potentials were recorded 503
with Natus (Pleasanton, CA) and Micromed (Italy). The sampling rate was 2048 Hz at Boston 504
Children's Hospital, 512 Hz or 1024 Hz at BWH, and 512 Hz at Xuanwu Hospital. Electrode 505
trajectories were determined based on clinical purposes for precisely localizing suspected 506
epileptogenic foci and surgically treating epilepsy (60). 507
508
Eye tracking procedures 509
Ten non-epilepsy healthy participants (23-35 years old, 9 female) performed the same 510
task while their eye movements were tracked with the EyeLink 1000 plus system (SR Research, 511
Canada) at a sampling rate of 500 Hz. The task paradigm was the same as the one for epilepsy 512
participants except that, before each block began, participants fixated on a center cross to ensure 513
that the EyeLink eye-tracking system was well-calibrated. Otherwise, a re-calibration session 514
ensued. The task was presented on a 19-inch CRT monitor (Sony Multiscan G520), and 515
participants sat about 21 inches away from the monitor screen. The tile size was 1x1 inches 516
(approximately 2.7x2.7 degrees of visual angle) as appeared on the screen. The study protocol 517
was approved by the institutional review board at Boston Children's Hospital, and each 518
participant completed the task with informed consent. All participants had normal or corrected-519
to-normal vision. All participants completed 16 blocks. 520
521
Behavioral analyses 522
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licenseavailable under a (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is made
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.03.27.534384doi: bioRxiv preprint
We created two computational models to simulate behavior assuming perfect memory 523
or no memory (chance performance, Figure 2A). The perfect memory model remembered all 524
revealed tiles without forgetting. The random model simulated random clicking. We calculated 525
the reaction time (RT, time between two clicks in a trial), n-since-pair (number of clicks since the 526
last time when a tile's matching pair was seen), n-since-last-click (the number of clicks since the 527
same tile was clicked), and n-times-seen (number of times the same image had been seen). For 528
n-since-pair and n-since-last-click, we excluded trials in which any tile was seen for the first time, 529
i.e., when a tile's matching pair had never been revealed, or there was no previous click. We 530
compared these variables for match and mismatch trials at each board size (Figure 2, 531
permutation test, 5,000 iterations, a=0.01). We defined random matches as a match trial where 532
the second tile had never been seen before; such trials were excluded from both the behavioral 533
and neurophysiological analyses. We used the F-test for linear regression models to assess 534
whether RT, n-since-pair, n-since-last-click, and n-times-seen significantly covary with board size. 535
The linear regression models' predictors were these four behavioral parameters and the 536
dependent variable the board size. We created separate models for match and mismatch trials 537
and 1st and 2nd tiles. 538
539
Electrode localization 540
Electrodes were localized using the iELVis (61) toolbox. We used Freesurfer (62) to 541
segment the preimplant magnetic resonance (MR) images, upon which post-implant CT was 542
rigidly registered. Electrodes were marked in the CT aligned to preimplant MRI using Bioimage 543
Suite (63). Each electrode was assigned to an anatomical location using the Desikan-Killiany (64) 544
atlas for subdural grids or strips or FreeSurfer's volumetric brain segmentation for depth 545
electrodes. For white matter electrodes, we also reported their closest gray matter locations. Out 546
of 1,750 electrodes in total, we included 676 bipolarly referenced electrodes in the gray matter 547
(Figure 3, Table S2) and 492 bipolarly referenced electrodes in the white matter (Figure S2, Table 548
S2). Five hundred eighty-two electrodes were not considered for analyses due to bipolar 549
referencing, locations in pathological sites, or electrodes containing large artifacts. Electrode 550

The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.03.27.534384doi: bioRxiv preprint
locations were mapped onto the MNI305 average brain via affine transformation (65) for display 551
purposes (e.g., Figure 3). 552
553
Preprocessing of intracranial field potential data 554
Bipolar subtraction was applied to each pair of neighboring electrodes on each shank of 555
depth electrodes or subdural grids/strips (66). A zero-phase digital notch filter (Matlab function 556
"filtfilt") was applied to the bipolarly subtracted broadband signals to remove the line frequency 557
at 60 Hz (BCH, BWH) or 50 Hz (Xuanwu) and their harmonics. For each electrode, trials whose 558
amplitudes (Voltagemax-Voltagemin) were larger than 5 standard deviations from the mean 559
amplitude across all trials were considered potential artifacts and discarded from further 560
analyses (67). For the first tile, the time window for artifact rejection was from 400 ms before the 561
click until 1 second after the average RT. For the second tile, the time window was [400 ms + 562
average RT] before the second click until 1 second after the second click. Across all electrodes, 563
we rejected 1.75% of all trials for the 1st tile and 1.73% for the second tile. 564
565
Time-frequency decomposition 566
The gamma band (30-150 Hz) power was computed using the Chronux toolbox (68). We 567
used a time-bandwidth product of 5 and 7 leading tapers, a moving window size of 200 ms, and 568
a step size of 10 ms (69). For each trial, the power was normalized by subtracting the mean 569
gamma band power during the baseline (400 ms before 1st tile) and dividing by the standard 570
deviation of the gamma power during the baseline. For all the participants, there were more 571
mismatch than match trials. In the raster plots, we subsampled the mismatch trials, keeping 572
those trials whose reaction times were closest to the mean reaction time of match trials. All 573
random matches were excluded from analyses. 574
575
Generalized linear model 576
We used generalized linear models (GLM) (70, 71) to analyze the relationship between 577
the gamma band power and behavioral parameters. We used two different GLMs, one using 578
neural responses between the 1st and the 2nd tiles and the other using neural responses after the 579
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licenseavailable under a (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is made
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.03.27.534384doi: bioRxiv preprint
2nd tile. For the first GLM, the time window started when the 1st tile was clicked and ended at a 580
time corresponding to the 90th percentile of the distribution of reaction times (time difference 581
between the 1st and the 2nd click, Figure 1A) for each participant. This criterion was a reasonable 582
tradeoff between minimum overlap with responses after the 2nd tile and the maximum amount 583
of information captured. For the second GLM, we used 1 second after the 2nd tile click as the 584
analysis window. The response variable to be fit by the GLM analyses was defined as the area 585
under the curve (AUC) of the gamma band power over the specified time windows. Table 1 586
describes the behavioral parameters that were considered as predictors in the models. 587
We performed a multicollinearity analysis to assess the presence of highly correlated 588
predictors that could impair the model's performance (72, 73). We calculated the variance 589
inflation factor (VIF) for each predictor to detect the presence of multicollinearities. A VIF of 1 590
indicates that there is no correlation with other predictors. The larger the VIF, the higher the 591
correlation. A VIF greater than 5 indicates a very high correlation that could significantly harm 592
the model's performance. For all participants in our analysis, the VIFs of all predictors were 593
smaller than 3 (Figure S3C-D). 594
For n-since-pair, we included the interaction term between this predictor and match (n-595
since-pair*match) to test the hypothesis that when a trial was a match, the strength of the neural 596
response after the first tile was modulated by how recently the tile's matching pair was seen for 597
the last time. The neurophysiological responses confirmed that this is a reasonable way to model 598
the data (Figure 6B). We represented image categories as predictor variables in the GLM by 599
including four out of the five categories (animal, food, vehicle, and person). We dropped the 600
"indoor" category to avoid falling into the "dummy variable trap" (74). For each predictor, we 601
calculated the parameter estimate (beta coefficient) from the least mean squares fit of the model 602
to the data, the t-statistic (beta divided by its standard error), and the p-value to test the effect 603
of each predictor on the neural responses. A beta coefficient or t-statistic of zero indicated that 604
the predictor did not affect the neural responses. A predictor was considered statistically 605
significant if the GLM model differed from a constant model (p<0.01) and the p-value for that 606
predictor was smaller than 0.01. 607

To determine if any brain region contained significantly more electrodes than expected 608
by chance considering any GLM predictor, we randomly sampled the same number (n) of 609
electrodes as those where that predictor was significant, from the total electrode population 610
(separately for gray and white matter electrodes) for 5,000 iterations. Taking the match predictor 611
for gray matter electrodes as an example, from the total of 676 gray matter electrode locations, 612
we randomly sampled 32 electrodes (the number of match-significant gray matter electrodes) 613
5,000 times, and calculated the p-value of any location, say insula, as the number of times when 614
n for insula and match-significant was less than n for insula sampled. If p<0.01, that brain region 615
was considered to have significantly more electrodes than expected by chance. 616
617
Decoding of match 618
We used a machine learning decoding approach to evaluate whether the neural 619
responses from a given brain region could predict whether the trial was a match or a mismatch. 620
For this analysis, we selected only those brain regions in which we had at least 12 electrodes. We 621
used two different decoders for each brain region, one using neural responses between the 1st 622
tile and 800 ms after the 1st tile click, and the other using the neural responses between the 2nd 623
tile and 800 ms after the 2nd tile click. We performed 200 iterations of 5-fold cross-validation for 624
each brain region and tile to split the trials into independent train and test sets (1,000 splits in 625
total). We concatenated the neural responses of electrodes within the same brain region, using 626
two different approaches: (i) taking all electrodes in each brain region, and (ii) randomly 627
subsampling 12 electrodes at each iteration. The number of match and mismatch trials was 628
normalized by random subsampling. To reduce the dimensionality of the neural responses, we 629
used principal component analysis (PCA). The PCA parameters were computed using only the 630
training data, and we selected the number of components that could explain 70% of the training 631
neural responses variance. We used support vector machines (SVM) with a linear kernel for the 632
binary classification (match or mismatch), using as the model inputs the PCA features computed 633
from the neural responses. We followed the same procedure to test whether the classification 634
performance was above chance, but we randomized the response variable (match or mismatch) 635
at every iteration. We calculated the p-value as the number of times when the accuracy using 636

random labels was above the average accuracy using the actual labels. If p<0.01, neural 637
responses of that brain region could predict match and mismatch above chance. 638

Figure 1. Experimental paradigm 814
A-C. Three consecutive trials in a 3×3 board. In each trial, two tiles were flipped sequentially in a 815 self-paced manner (1st tile, then 2nd tile). If the two tiles contained different images (A, C, 816 mismatch), both tiles reset to their original active (black) state after 1 second. If both tiles 817 contained the same image (B, match), they turned green after 1 second and stayed green for the 818 remainder of the block. Three behavioral predictors used in the generalized linear models (GLM) 819 are defined here: reaction time (the time between the 1st and 2nd tile within a trial), n-since-last-820 click (the number of clicks elapsed since the same tile was clicked last), and n-since-pair (the 821 number of clicks elapsed since the last time a given tile’s matching pair was clicked). Each tile 822 spanned approximately 2 degrees of visual angle (dva) in size. See also Movie S1. 823 824 825

Figure S1
Figure S1. Participants’ eye movements tracked the clicked locations. Eye movements were similar during match and mismatch trials for the 1st tile, and for the 2nd tile before click time, but not for the 2nd tile after click time, when equalizing the reaction time and distances between the 1st and 2nd tiles. Line traces (mean±s.e.m) indicate the average distance in visual angle between gaze and the center of the tile clicked for match (green) and mismatch (black) trials. Reaction times (RT) and distances between the 1st and 2nd tiles were equalized (mean RT ± 200ms; mean distance ± 3°). A. No significant difference in eyemovements between match and mismatch was found during clicking the 1st tile. B. No significant difference in eye movements between match and mismatch was found before clicking the 2nd tile. Participants’ gaze moved faster away from the 2nd tile in match trials than mismatch trials after the click: within the 1 second window after time zero, the distance from the gaze to the center of the tile was on average 1.76 dva (degrees of visual angle) larger for match than mismatch trials.

Figure S4. Neural signals in the white matter reflect novelty and familiarity Panels show an example electrode in the white matter whose closest gray matter region is the left lateral orbitofrontal cortex (arrow in D). This figure follows the format of Figure 4 in the main text. A. T-statistic of each predictor in the GLM analysis (Methods). Asterisks indicate statistically significant predictors for the neural signals. B. Z-scored gamma band power aligned to the 1st tile onset (solid vertical line) for novel tiles (blue), unfamiliar tiles (n-since-last-click>1, yellow), and more familiar tiles (n-since-last-click=1, red). The vertical dashed line indicates the mean reaction time. The time axis extends from 400 ms before the click to 500 ms after the average reaction time. C. Raster plot showing the z-scored gamma power in individual trials ordered by first-click and then larger to smaller n-since-last-click; division indicated by white horizontal lines and colored vertical lines. D. Locations of all white matter electrodes where n-since-last-click was a significant predictor during the 1st tile. Orange: n-since-last-click; red: both n-since-last-click and first-click were significant predictors. All electrodes were reflected on one hemisphere for display purposes.
